definition: altar lamp burning day and night
Ming Dynasty (1368-1644)/surname Ming/Ming (c. 2000 BC), fourth of the legendary Flame Emperors, 炎帝[Yan2 di4] descended from Shennong 神農|神农[Shen2 nong2] Farmer God
bright/opposite: dark 暗[an4]/(of meaning) clear/to understand/next/public or open/wise/generic term for a sacrifice to the gods

sentences.english: There is also an altar lamp burning whale oil.
sentences.chinese: 還有用鯨魚油做成的長明燈。

sentences.english: It was supposed to be an "everlasting lamp."
The two votary lamps in front of the figure of Buddha are glittering slightly.
sentences.chinese: 佛像前面點着兩盞長明燈，閃着微微的淡光。

sentences.english: Books are the ever-burning lamps of accumulated wisdom.
sentences.chinese: 書籍是積聚智慧的長明燈。

sentences.english: Books are the ever-burning lamps wisdom.
sentences.chinese: 書籍是積聚智慧的長明燈。

sentences.english: A Buddhist shrine stands on the other side of the room, but the candles have burned out.
sentences.chinese: 而對面的佛龕上，長明燈已然熄滅。

sentences.english: Squid that is transparent except big eyes, with a bright bulb lighting in its chest.
sentences.chinese: 全身透明的烏賊，在胸腔中點着一盞長明燈。

definition: lit. the river that divides Chu and Han/fig. a line that divides rival territories/the mid-line between sides on a Chinese chessboard
see 驚慌失措|惊慌失措[jing1 huang1 shi1 cuo4]
to die without a burial site/to die a pauper/a tragic end
pinyin: si3 wu2 zang4 shen1 zhi1 di4

definition: to whisper to one another's ear
feng shui master/geomancer/stock figure in folk tales, as a wise adviser or a charlatan
to revisit old haunts (idiom); down memory lane
